newsitem.title: PERU: Six foreign oil groups bid for Peru's block X.
newsitem.headline: Six foreign oil groups bid for Peru's block X.

text.p: Six foreign petroleum groups formally bid for the rights to Peru's state-owned oil block X, privatization officials said Wednesday.

They named the groups as Canada's Norcen Energy Resources Ltd., China's CNPC America Peru S.A., Pennzoil Co. and Petrosantander Peru S.A., Argentina's Compania Perez Companc, and a consortium of Argentina's Pluspetrol Corp and Peru's Grana y Montero Petrolera S.A.
Peru had set a minimum bid price of $65 million for the block, but officials gave no financial details of the offers.
The winner of the auction, to be announced on Friday, will have a minimum spending requirement of $25 million over five years.

The block, with proven reserves of 49 million barrels of crude oil, lies 720 miles (1,150 km) north of Lima in the Talara region. The contract being offered by state oil company Petroperu includes a 30-year lisence to extract oil and a 40- year licence for natural gas.
The block currently produces 17,000 barrels per day (bpd) of crude oil from its roughly 39,000 hectare area, officials said.
Petroperu also owns a refinery in the Talara region, which it plans to auction as part of the state company's piecemeal sell-off.
In the last auction in August, Mobil bought Petroperu's lubricants unit, Petrolube, for $18.9 million.
This sale followed the company's June auctions, when the government sold a 60 percent stake in the La Pampilla refinery near Lima and the rights to develop oil block 8/8X in the northeastern jungle.
A consortium led by Spain's Repsol SA bought the La Pampilla stake for $180.5 million, and a consortium led by Pluspetrol won the oil block with a bid of $142.2 million.
